nodes.bodyText:
As per https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/String.html#equalsIgnoreCase(java.lang.String),
Two characters c1 and c2 are considered the same ignoring case if at least one of the following is true:

The two characters are the same (as compared by the == operator)
Calling Character.toLowerCase(Character.toUpperCase(char)) on each character produces the same result

Character.toLowerCase(Character.toUpperCase(char)) can be used instead of String. toUpperCase().
There are two public boolean equalsIgnoreCase(String string) within String.java, Java 8 version seems missing the fix.
Please add the testcase supplied within the issue to Test_String.java.

There is special handling in the code for the last character. When adding tests, it can test for the turkish i as the only character (which is also the last), and also when something else is the last character.

Please add a few more testcases such as \u0131 & \u0130 are at middle or end of a string instead of just a single character string.
In addition, could you verify all test cases also pass with -XX:+CompactStrings?
nitpick: please add parentheses for this condition, same for following similar conditions.

Is this change introduced to fix an existing equalsIgnoreCase problem?
private static int toUpperCase(int codePoint) invokes Character.toUpperCase() internally but avoid it for case codePoint < 128 apparently for performance reason.

I tested locally with toUpperCase(int codePoint) and Character.toUpperCase() and the simple test case results were the same. So it seems it would be better to keep the existing toUpperCase(int codePoint) usage, for performance purposes.
This makes me think that we should use Character.toLowerCase(toUpperCase(int codePoint)) in the spots where we're now using Character.toLowerCase(Character.toUpperCase()).

This makes me think that we should use Character.toLowerCase(toUpperCase(int codePoint)) in the spots where we're now using Character.toLowerCase(Character.toUpperCase()).

Yup, probably can go toLowerCase(toUpperCase(int codePoint)).
In addition, it seems String.compareToIgnoreCase() is doing the right thing, but could you add a test for it against the Turkish characters reported as well?

Existing code checks (charAtO1Last <= 255 && charAtO2Last <= 255) along with || Character.toLowerCase(charAtO1Last) != Character.toLowerCase(charAtO2Last)), now it is required alone as one of conditions, it doesn't seem right.
Does this change pass a personal build test suite like sanity.functional?

Currently waiting on the results of my personal build test suite with the current pushed changes, will update once available.
In the meantime, I tested locally using (char1 != char2) && (compareValue(char1) != compareValue(char2) (removed (charAtO1Last <= 255 && charAtO2Last <= 255) and swapped Character.toLowerCase(Character.toUpperCase() with compareValue()), and the expected behaviour was seen. This logic is currently being used here on line 1839:
https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/f2e8dfa4346808869c9e47822f725a10678ac97d/jcl/src/java.base/share/classes/java/lang/String.java#L1836-L1841
compareValue(char/int/byte) internally calls Character.toLowerCase(Character.toUpperCase(char/int/byte))
https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/f2e8dfa4346808869c9e47822f725a10678ac97d/jcl/src/java.base/share/classes/java/lang/String.java#L1457-L1478
I'll run another build with these changes to confirm if it's functionally correct.

Both the build with the currently pushed code and the build with my local changes passed sanity.functional. Will be pushing my local changes, which contain the modifications discussed in the review comments.
Pls fix the comment, which mentions lower case although the code uses upper case.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1794,29 +1794,32 @@ public boolean equalsIgnoreCase(String string) {
 			byte byteAtO1Last = helpers.getByteFromArrayByIndex(s1Value, s1len - 1);

nodes.bodyText: Pls fix comment here as well.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -5811,17 +5818,19 @@ public boolean equalsIgnoreCase(String string) {
 			byte byteAtO1Last = helpers.getByteFromArrayByIndex(s1Value, s1len - 1);

nodes.bodyText: @fjeremic fyi. We're losing the <= 256 optimization here, do you think it's worth putting this into compareValue()?
I guess that doesn't work as is, we'll have to create a new helper function that takes both chars.
Yeah should be fine as the check has moved into charValuesEqualIgnoreCase.

@pshipton Here's the new helper. This is now being used anytime we are checking equality for two chars in equalsIgnoreCase() and regionMatches().
I've locally tested against the test cases in this PR (expected results are seen), but can run a sanity.functional test build if preferred.
Local testing is fine. I'll be running PR testing anyway.

Is this change required for functional correctness at enableCompression cases? i.e., does the testcase failed with -XX:+CompactStrings as well? Otherwise, additional toLowerCase() checking is being introduced here.

The testcase from the issue fails with -XX:+CompactStrings, but the failure is not occurring in the enableCompression code. The failure is still in the "regular" equalsIgnoreCase()/regionMatches() code when -XX:+CompactStrings is used.
So functionally, charValuesEqual() is not necessary for enableCompression cases (does an extra toLowerCase() check) -- I'll revert to the original.
Similar question here and also for later enableCompression cases.
This method name might be mis-leading, it really means charValuesEqualIgnoreCase, right?
This method should also be static as it does not use any fields.
This method is missing in Java 8 pConfig.

Added this method to the Java 8 section of String; made compareValue(int/char/byte) in Java 9+ section static as well, since they do not use any non-static fields (the Java 8 versions are already static).
Is it possible to change this to static?
Yes, updated

I think we may be missing the charAtO1 != charAtO2 check here. I see the check is duplicated in charValuesEqualIgnoreCase which seems suboptimal. I think we should take the check out of charValuesEqualIgnoreCase and always perform it upfront before calling charValuesEqualIgnoreCase, otherwise performance will suck.
Moved the char1 != char2 check back outside of charValuesEqualIgnoreCase()
